title: Future Student
text: We are hiring! Check out what we are looking for in a future PhD student.

title: Future Student
text: We are hiring! Check out what we are looking for in a future PhD student.

title: Research Vision & Infrastructure
text: We are in a new era of geospatial science defined by cloud platforms, massive sensor networks, and the rise of GeoAI. The GATOR Lab addresses the critical bottleneck where our ability to collect data has outpaced our ability to analyze it.

title: Research Vision & Infrastructure
text: We are in a new era of geospatial science defined by cloud platforms, massive sensor networks, and the rise of GeoAI. The GATOR Lab addresses the critical bottleneck where our ability to collect data has outpaced our ability to analyze it.

title: Research Vision & Infrastructure
text:
Our Computing Stack
To stay at the cutting edge of Scalable Geospatial Data Science, we utilize top-notch infrastructure. We are currently in the process of setting up our core infrastructure which will include:

HiPerGator AI: Direct access to the University of Florida‚Äôs supercomputer, the most powerful AI system in U.S. academia.
In-Lab AI Workstation: A dedicated high-performance GPU machine for rapid local development and model prototyping.
Cloud-Native Workflows: We specialize in leveraging high-performance computing and cloud-native technologies to overcome spatiotemporal analysis bottlenecks.

title: Research Vision & Infrastructure
text:
Interdisciplinary Impact
Our work translates modern computing into real-world solutions, for example:

Environmental Resilience: Modeling coastal change and climate impacts (e.g., our EPA-funded ‚ÄúFuture Shorelines‚Äù project).
Spatial Data Science: Interrogating the integrity and bias of spatial data in human systems.
Precision Sensing & Analytics: Integrating traditional geomatics (including surveying, photogrammetry, and remote sensing) with modern data science to enhance the accuracy and reliability of spatial infrastructure.

title: Join the GATOR Lab
text:
We are currently seeking two fully funded PhD students to join our team.


Focus on cloud-native workflows, Large Language Models (LLMs) for geospatial reasoning and and scalable geospatial data science.



Primarily work on the ‚ÄúFuture Shorelines‚Äù project to model sea-level rise and coastal change, and bring cutting-edge computing to solve an environmental problem.
We also welcome original research proposals that align with the lab‚Äôs core mission and expertise.

title: Join the GATOR Lab
text:
We are currently seeking two fully funded PhD students to join our team.


Focus on cloud-native workflows, Large Language Models (LLMs) for geospatial reasoning and and scalable geospatial data science.



Primarily work on the ‚ÄúFuture Shorelines‚Äù project to model sea-level rise and coastal change, and bring cutting-edge computing to solve an environmental problem.
We also welcome original research proposals that align with the lab‚Äôs core mission and expertise.

title: Join the GATOR Lab
text:
What We Value
Above all, we value intellectual curiosity and a critical mindset. We are looking for researchers who don‚Äôt just apply tools, but interrogate them. We are not afraid to ask interesting but difficult questions, and engage with challenging problems. You will thrive here if you are passionate about open science and eager to solve complex spatial problems through a data-science lens.

title: Join the GATOR Lab
text:
Requirements

MS degree: We are looking for candidates with a masters degree or equivalent in GIScience, Computer Science, Statistics, Data Science, Geography or a related field.
Research: Peer-reviewed publications are not a hard requirement but we expect candidates to have a track record of research.
Satisfying all UF graduate admission requirements if an offer is made.

title: Join the GATOR Lab
text:
How to Apply
Review of applications is ongoing. Please email Dr.¬†Levente Juh√°sz (join@gatorlab.io ‚Äî Note: UF email available Jan 2026) with:

Your CV and a link to your GitHub/Portfolio.
A Brief Statement of Interest explaining WHY GATOR Lab and HOW you fit our pillars. This is very important. We are not just looking for researchers, we are looking for the right fit. Be creative, authentic, and tell us why want to join the GATOR Lab.


Join us at the University of Florida to build the future of Geospatial Data Science.

title: New dashboard for GIScience journal analysis
text:
Building on the 2024 publication, ‚ÄúAssessing publication trends in selected GIScience journals‚Äù in IJGIS, the GATOR Lab is excited to release an interactive companion dashboard. This tool is designed to help the community navigate the evolving landscape of our field.
The dashboard provides a quantitative look at 24 core GIScience venues, tracking their evolution from 2018 through 2024 (with ongoing data updates in the future).



International collaboration network in GIScience research




Selecting a publication venue is often based on ‚Äúgut feeling‚Äù or a single metric like Impact Factor. This tool allows for a more refined, multi-dimensional assessment of the field:

Meta Rankings: Compare journals using a composite index of eight different metrics (IF, CiteScore, SJR, SNIP, etc.) to see a more stable picture of ‚Äúprestige‚Äù.
Open Access Trends: Monitor the shift towards OA
Collaboration Networks: Interactively explore how jurisdictions (countries) collaborate. Our data shows that while the field is growing, the Global South remains underrepresented‚Ä¶ a gap we hope to highlight and help close to build an inclusive community.
Cost vs.¬†Impact: View the relationship between Article Processing Charges (APCs) and journal rankings to find the best ‚Äúvalue‚Äù for your research.




In the spirit of open principles, the dashboard is built using Shinylive. This means it runs entirely in your web browser via WebAssembly, which in turn requires no backend server or 3rd party resources. It is private, and permanently accessible. The initial Shiny dashboard is a reimplementation and expansion of the 2024 IJGIS article and it was built by Jorge Corcino. Stay tuned as we are releasing the updated dataset and the source code of the dashboard very soon.



We want to be clear about our view on using journal metrics to evaluate research impact. Quite frankly, we are not a fan of them. However, we need to be realistic and understand that it is a common practice in the academic community to use them. Think about going up for promotion, demonstrating the impact of your work, or justifying funding applications. Most of these decisions rely on some sort of metrics, and journal metrics are a common choice, so in a sense they are a necessary evil. While we may fundamentally disagree with putting to much emphasis on journal metrics, a lot of us are still at the mercy of them and therefore we are releasing this dashboard to build a better, more holistic understanding of the GIScience journal landscape.
On the bright side, better approaches to assess research impact are rapidly emerging, and we hope to see more of them in the future. A good resource to get started is the San Francisco Declaration on Research Assessment that recognizes and formalizes the need to improve the ways in which the outputs of scholarly research are evaluated.
With all its flaws, we still hope that our GIScience journal assessment dashboard will serve as a useful resource for everyone from students selecting their first submission venue to senior researchers optimizing publication strategies to maximize the impact of their work.
Explore the dashboard here or launch the Full Screen version.

title: Geographic Expansion and Improvements of the Future Shorelines Tool
text:
Abstract
This project expands and enhances Future Shorelines, a geospatial decision support tool designed to increase the climate resiliency of nature-based solutions in South Florida. By integrating high-resolution topographic and bathymetric data with NOAA sea-level rise trajectories, the tool provides parcel-level visualizations and cross-sections to assist practitioners in siting and designing living shorelines. This phase upgrades the database with novel attributes‚Äîincluding seagrass coverage and sediment type‚Äîand extends geographic coverage across Martin and Palm Beach Counties, as well as implements functionality improvements, such as dynamic profiling. Supported by a growing network of 23 partners, the project leverages stakeholder input to streamline permitting and improve coastal adaptation planning.

title: Geographic Expansion and Improvements of the Future Shorelines Tool
text:
Funding
Original funding was provided by theEnvironmental Protection Agency to Florida International University. Since Dr.¬†Juh√°sz joined the University of Florida the GATOR Lab participates through a sub-award from FIU.

title: Geospatial Analytics, Technology & Open Research
text:

Noteüíºüßë‚Äçüéì We are looking for 2 PhD Students to join our team in Fall 2026!





Welcome to the Geospatial Analytics, Technology and Open Research (GATOR) Lab at the University of Florida. We are part of the Geomatics Program in the School of Forest, Fisheries and Geomatics Sciences at UF/IFAS.
We are located at the Fort Lauderdale Research and Education Center within the Miami metropolitan area.


Broadly speaking, we are interested in harnessing the latest technological and methodological advancements in geographic information science. Our work focuses on the convergence of geospatial science, artificial intelligence, and scalable computing. Our research develops scientifically rigorous and scalable frameworks to transform massive geospatial datasets into actionable insights for environmental and societal challenges.




Scalable Geospatial Data Science & Analytics: Leveraging high-performance computing and cloud-native technologies to overcome the analysis bottleneck of massive spatiotemporal datasets.
GeoAI and Responsible Automation: Harnessing Large Language Models (LLMs) and agentic AI for geospatial reasoning, while establishing safeguards against geographic bias and misinformation.
Open Source, Open Data, and Societal Impact: Ensuring research transparency and community value by translating advanced methods into sustainable open-source tools and accessible data products.

title: Welcome to the GATOR Lab!
text: I am excited to announce the launch of the Geospatial Analytics, Technology and Open Research (GATOR) Lab at the University of Florida. I accepted a position of Assistant Professor of Geospatial Analytics in Geomatics from the Spring 2026 semester. This marks my return to UF after a 7-year spell at Florida International University as research faculty. I am beyond excited to be back at UF and to continue my research in geospatial analytics, technology and open research.

title: Welcome to the GATOR Lab!
text: I am excited to announce the launch of the Geospatial Analytics, Technology and Open Research (GATOR) Lab at the University of Florida. I accepted a position of Assistant Professor of Geospatial Analytics in Geomatics from the Spring 2026 semester. This marks my return to UF after a 7-year spell at Florida International University as research faculty. I am beyond excited to be back at UF and to continue my research in geospatial analytics, technology and open research.

title: Welcome to the GATOR Lab!
text:
Why GATOR?
The GATOR acronym is a play on words. It stands for Geospatial Analytics, Technology and Open Research. It represents the Geospatial (or Geomatics), Analytics, Technology and Open Research pillars of my research. As an alumnus, and now faculty member I also found it important to pay tribute to the Florida Gatorsüêä, and ground our lab‚Äôs mission within The Gator Nation.

title: Welcome to the GATOR Lab!
text:
What‚Äôs ahead?
I am currently in the process of setting up our core infrastructure. The next and ongoing major step is to recruit. I am currently seeking two fully funded PhD students to join the lab. This is an exciting opportunity not only for me, but for the first few lab members, who will be an important part of establishing the lab‚Äôs culture and direction. I am not just looking for the usual candidates, but for people who are passionate about open science and eager to solve complex spatial problems through a data-science lens. While an excellent academic background is important, I am more interested in your intellectual curiosity and a critical mindset. I can‚Äôt stress the importance of this enough. Finding a mutual fit will make or break this experience. Committing to a long PhD program is a major decision. I want to commit to your future success as much as the success of the GATOR Lab, therefore, I am very intentional and selective about who I recruit. I expect you to be the same with making sure that the GATOR Lab and my mentorship are a good fit for you. With that being said, I am interested in the person behind the CV, and I am open to discussing your interests and aspirations. If you are interested in joining the lab, please consult the join page for more information.
It is my hope that the lab will extend beyond PhD students. In the future, I plan to recruit postdocs, visiting scholars, and collaborators to push the boundaries of geospatial science. I am also interested in working with industry partners, and I am open to discussing potential collaborations, which will benefit the lab in many ways: it will inform our research, teaching, and help us stay at the cutting edge of geospatial analytics and technology.

title: Welcome to the GATOR Lab!
text:
Where are we located?
We are located in sunny South Florida, at the Fort Lauderdale Research & Education Center. While not being located in Gainesville may seem unusual, it is a great location for research and collaboration. South Florida (Miami - Ft. Lauderdale - West Palm Beach) is a vibrant metropolitan area. It is a great place to be, and it also provides a great environment for research and collaboration: it is a hub of innovation and creativity, with a diverse population and a rich cultural heritage. It also lies at the forefront of man-made and environmental challenges waiting to be solved by science.

title: GIScience Journal Assessment Dashboard
text:
We monitor key geographic information science (GIScience) journals to track the evolution of the field as well as to provide a resource for researchers in the GIScience community and related fields to optimize their publication strategies. The dashboard is based on the paper titled ‚ÄúAssessing publication trends in selected GIScience journals‚Äù.






TipLaunch Dashboard



The dashboard is built with shinylive and it runs completely in your browser using WebAssembly. It may take a minute or so to load the R packages and data initially. Sinylive caches these resources efficiently so once everything is loaded, the dashboard should be responsive even during subsequent interactions.



  
    
      Loading...
    
    Initializing Dashboard...
    Downloading engine & data (first run ~30s)
  
  



Launch Full Screen Dashboard

title: Levente Juh√°sz, PhD
text: Dr.¬†Levente Juh√°sz is an Assistant Professor in the Geomatics program at the University of Florida. He earned his PhD in Geomatics from UF in 2018 before serving as a Research Associate Professor at Florida International University. His career is dedicated to pushing the boundaries of geospatial analytics through innovation, interdisciplinarity, and community-driven open science.

title: Levente Juh√°sz, PhD
text: Dr.¬†Levente Juh√°sz is an Assistant Professor in the Geomatics program at the University of Florida. He earned his PhD in Geomatics from UF in 2018 before serving as a Research Associate Professor at Florida International University. His career is dedicated to pushing the boundaries of geospatial analytics through innovation, interdisciplinarity, and community-driven open science.

title: Levente Juh√°sz, PhD
text:
Research Interests
His work focuses on the convergence of geospatial science, artificial intelligence, and scalable computing. Key areas include:

GeoAI: Developing frameworks for geospatial reasoning using Large Language Models (LLMs).
Spatial Data Integrity: Interrogating the quality, bias, and malicious defacement of crowdsourced data (e.g., VGI and OpenStreetMap).
Climate Resilience: Building scalable environmental decision support systems, such as the EPA-funded ‚ÄúFuture Shorelines‚Äù project.

title: Levente Juh√°sz, PhD
text:
Lab History
Founded in 2026, the GATOR Lab marks Dr.¬†Juh√°sz‚Äôs return to the University of Florida to establish a high-performance hub for geospatial data science.

title: Levente Juh√°sz, PhD
text:
Outside of Research
I enjoy the outdoors and endurance sports. My favorite activities are road cycling, obstacle course racing, and more recently ultra running.

title: Jorge Corcino
text: Jorge is currently a graduate student at Florida International University majoring in Data Science & AI. He is originally from the British Virgin Islands and is currently based in Miami, FL. His backgroud is in Information Systems / Computer Science. While making a pivot towards data science he discovered his passion for geospatial data. At home, he works for the BVI Electricity Corporation, and he expects to utilize his data analytics and GIS skills when he returns.

title: Jorge Corcino
text: Jorge is currently a graduate student at Florida International University majoring in Data Science & AI. He is originally from the British Virgin Islands and is currently based in Miami, FL. His backgroud is in Information Systems / Computer Science. While making a pivot towards data science he discovered his passion for geospatial data. At home, he works for the BVI Electricity Corporation, and he expects to utilize his data analytics and GIS skills when he returns.

title: Jorge Corcino
text:
Research Interests
Jorge‚Äôs research interests include blending traditional data science with geography and environmental sciences. He is working on developing decision support systems for coastal resilience. More recently, he is also exploring the potential of Agentic AI.
